title: AB 2687
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 23152 of the Vehicle Code in California prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. The BAC limit is based on grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood or grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath. If a chemical test shows a BAC of 0.08% or higher within three hours of driving, it is presumed that the person was over the limit while driving. It is illegal for a person addicted to drugs to drive. A person with 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood cannot drive a commercial vehicle. If a chemical test within three hours of driving shows 0.04% or more alcohol, it is presumed the person was over the limit while driving. Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive a vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood when a passenger for hire is present. A passenger for hire is someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. If a chemical test within three hours of driving shows 0.04% or more alcohol, it is assumed the person was over the limit while driving. Additionally, it is unlawful to drive under the influence of any drug. It is illegal to drive under the influence of any drug or a combination of alcohol and drugs. The Vehicle Code prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol, with specific limits on blood alcohol content, that result in bodily injury to others. In a prosecution, it is presumed that a person had 0.08% or more alcohol in their blood while driving if a chemical test within three hours confirms the same. Neglecting any duty while driving does not require proof of violating a specific code section. It is illegal to drive a commercial vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood, causing bodily injury to others. A chemical test within three hours can be used to prove the alcohol level while driving. It is unlawful to drive a motor vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood if a passenger for hire is present and causes bodily injury to another person. The presence of alcohol can be presumed if the driver had 0.04% or more in their blood at the time of driving. Driving with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood is illegal if a chemical test within three hours after driving confirms the presence of alcohol. It is illegal to drive under the influence of any drug or a combination of alcohol and drugs, leading to bodily injury to another person. The act does not require reimbursement under the California Constitution as it pertains to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
